content.description:
Good pockets lead to the ledge, then it's more pockets (including a couple of wonderful mailslots) to a strenuous overhang. The moves over the overhang are somewhat inobvious and leave you crying for better feet. Once above the overhang a tenuous move or two leads to another, slopey ledge and a short respite.

The last section leads through a tricky sequence with occasionally-less-than-satisfying pockets to a final ledge, upon which you stand to clip the chains.
content.location: Fourth from the left on the blue-gray wall.

content.description: Pockets and a few edgy sidepulls make for a couple of potentially tricky moves to a ledge. A couple of big pockets lead from the ledge, followed by some head-scratching to get to the next truly positive holds. Body positioning and some burly moves lead you over the bulge. A brief, easier section then leads to thin moves and a good rest position. Pockets and edges combine for the last, nerve-wracking moves to the chains.
content.location: Third from the left on the blue-gray wall.

content.description:
Relatively easy climbing through two bolts to a ledge, then up and over the rounded roof on pockets and edges.

Once over the roof, a somewhat perplexing sequence with inscrutable feet leads to momentary relief, followed by another short, thin section to the chains.
content.location: Second from the left on the gray wall. Starts at the low point below the gray wall and heads straight up to the chains.

content.description:
A fun, technical start on vertical, blue-streaked limestone leads to a ledge. Next is a strenuous, awkward roof followed by edges and pockets on lower-angled rock which lead to the chains.

It's possible to do the lower part using the corner to the right at various points. The longer you wait to touch the corner, the more fun it is, but also more difficult.
content.location: On the uphill end of the blue-gray wall. The start is a blank-looking, blue-streaked section bracketed by shallow corners on each side.

content.description: A sequency, somewhat balancy start using wonderful pockets leads to a burly, reachy crux which is then followed by tricky slabbery using less-than-satisfying feet.
content.location: The left-most route at the crag. The bolts on this one are all wedge bolts; different from the other routes on this wall which all have Power-bolts.
